main event: A ground-visual observation of round, bright objects drifting to the southwest for 1 hour and 15 minutes, 6 miles west of Darrington, Washington on December 6, 1957.
interesting points: The observation duration and celestial position suggested the possibility of the object being a very bright Venus.
Astro plot and astro charts indicated the observed duration matching the planet Venus's position.
The report considered possibilities such as balloon, aircraft, or astronomical object.
The sighting location was provided as 6 miles west of Darrington, Washington.
Weather balloons released from Seattle and Tatoosh were noted to be at an altitude of about 42,000 feet, potentially relevant to the observation.
sighted object: Bright, round objects drifting to the southwest
